items.title: slate star codex / astral codex ten
items.desc: a psychiatrist who writes about coordination failures, truth-seeking, linguistics, medicine, and active inference — always with wit, sometimes with rigor.

items.title: putanumonit
items.desc: bayesian thinking applied to dating, politics, and life. rationality that's fun to read.

items.title: carl shulman
items.desc: possibly the most careful thinker alive on tech trajectories and their implications. rarely writes in public, always worth reading.

items.title: sonia calico
items.desc: taiwanese dj/producer. experimental club, deconstructed, relentless energy.

items.title: acid pauli
items.desc: psychedelic electronic music. organic, deeply textured, impossible to sit still to.

items.title: nils frahm
items.desc: intimate piano with electronic textures, ambient techno-influenced soundscapes.

items.title: hanabi
items.desc: cooperative card game where you can see everyone's hand but your own. pure coordination problem.

items.title: secret hitler
items.desc: watching your friends lie to your face is a great way to build trust.

items.title: sean carroll's mindscape
items.desc: a physicist with range: consciousness, morality, quantum mechanics, aliens.

items.title: the knowledge project
items.desc: decision-making and mental models. the barbara coloroso episode is secretly a masterclass in human interaction.

items.title: you are not so smart
items.desc: cognitive biases, self-delusion, and why your brain lies to you. the ads are annoying but the content earns them.

items.title: actually possible: thoughts on utopia
items.desc: the most beautiful thing i've read about what a good future could actually look like. not sci-fi, not naive — just careful, honest hope.

items.title: the economies that are home to the poorest billions need to grow
items.desc: why redistribution alone can't solve poverty — the global average income is $16/day. the arithmetic case for growth.

items.title: cfar handbook
items.desc: the guide to applied rationality. techniques for noticing where your functioning breaks down and fixing it.

items.title: the fragile world hypothesis
items.desc: civilization is a tightrope walk — fragility isn't a bug, it's the natural state of complex systems. the point isn't to be scared or to clamp down with heavy-handed control. it's that staying on the rope requires thoughtful governance at every scale, and within those bounds, you go as hard as you can.

items.title: coasean bargaining at scale
items.desc: how ai agents could reduce transaction costs to near-zero, enabling the kind of decentralised negotiation that makes most political disagreements dissolve.

items.title: staring into the abyss as a core life skill
items.desc: the practice of deeply examining the hard questions you'd rather avoid. short, practical, and quietly life-changing.

items.title: sense8
items.desc: eight strangers across the world share consciousness.

items.title: everything everywhere all at once
items.desc: multiverse absurdism that becomes the most moving film about love and laundry.
